    Takes a polygon and some indexes as in data that gives an approximation of the given polygon, that is try to represent it in some way.

Detailed Description

-+-+-+- READ ME -+-+-+-

To gain greater understanding of this code one should read Alexander Kolesnikovs paper "A fast near-optimal min-# polygonal approximation of digitized curves" (P1) or "Reduced-search dynamic programing for approximation of polygonal curves" (P2). Both papers can be found (@ the time this was written) on Alexanders homepage http://www.cs.joensuu.fi/~koles/.

"iterations" tells the algorithm how many times it should try to run on its own out data as in data to improve it. If will break if no improvement is done at any given step. It is reasonable to keep this value around 10.

"maxSizeOfSegment" tells the algorithm how long pieces of a polygon it should try to optimize in one run, if a polygon is longer than this it will be split up into pieces that are approximately maxSizeOfSegment long. This is done to avoid cases where N and M are large and thus time consuming.

"W" should be between 6 and 8. Altho it should be ok to use anything >= 1. If W = 1 is used this filter will do nothing useful. If W >= M a complete search of the statespace will be done and we guarantee global minimum according to the given costFunction. While W < M we can not give such guarantees altho it is usually the case that we find global minimum if we keep W between 6 - 8.

double GfxFilterUtil::costFunction (  int  i,
int  j,
int *  x,
int *  y
)  [inline, static]
 

Calculates the sum of all cost on the line Pi - Pj and the point.

Parameters:
i the index for one of the points we want to use as an approximation of part of the polygon.
j the index for one of the points we want to use as an approximation of part of the polygon.
x contains the x values of the coordinates of the polygon.
y contains the y values of the coordinates of the polygon.
Returns:
the cost for approximating part of the polygon with points i and j. That is removing all the points between i and j.

Calculates the smallest distance between point k and line i - j times the distance between points k-1 and k+1 divided by 2.

Parameters:

j the index of point j.
k the index of point k.
x the x coords.
y the y coords.
nbrOfPointsInBetweenij the number of points in the polygon between point i and point j.
Returns:
the cost for point k in regard to line i-j.

xyhelper converts from mc2coords to non projected coords.
pointsBegin doh.
pointsEnd doooh.
W tells the algirithm how wide the bounding corridor should be, good values seams to be around 6-8.

Splits the polygon in pieces that are around maxSizeOfSegment big and lets the final step of the algorithm run on those pieces.

This is done to speed things up a bit.

template<class INT_PUSH_BACKABLE, class INT_SEQUENCE, class XYHELPER, class POINT_ITERATOR>
void GfxFilterUtil::runFilter (  INT_PUSH_BACKABLE &  outIndeces,
const INT_SEQUENCE &  rsPath,
const XYHELPER &  xyhelper,
const POINT_ITERATOR &  pointsBegin,
const POINT_ITERATOR &  pointsEnd,
int  W
)  [static]
 

Takes a polygon and some indexes as in data that gives an approximation of the given polygon, that is try to represent it in some way.

The filter then try to improve the approximation using an algorithm that is described in P1 and P2. Returns the total error for the approximation and does a pushback of al the indexes that it considers to be useful.

Parameters:
outIndeces the container that we return our final indeces to.
referencePath tha path that we use as a guide when we determine where to search to be as efficient as possible.
xyhelper converts from mc2coords to non projected coords.
pointsBegin doh.
pointsEnd doooh.
W tells the algirithm how wide the bounding corridor should be, good values seams to be around 6-8.
